NewWords.WordPhrase: sth. that is very easy to do 不费吹灰之力的事
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Shopping on line is a piece of cake for the five-year-old.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 得到心中渴望的东西
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was making great efforts to achieve his heart's desires.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (esp. AmE) (pl alumni) a (male) former student of a school, college or university （男）校友
n. (pl anchorwomen) （广播、电视节目的）女主持人  anchor n. 锚
ad. on or to one side 在一边；向一边
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I have a little money set aside for emergencies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 每隔…时间（或距离）；不时
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The interview continued, with Smith breaking off at intervals to consult his notes.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 棒球
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Baseball is a very popular sport in America.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. (old use, now used chiefly in the following phrase) wait for 等待  bide one's time wait patiently for a chance 等待良机
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His political rivals are biding their time until after the election for a chance to attack his polices.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 简报，通讯；会刊；公告
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The company publishes an annual staff bulletin.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 生性
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is by nature rather an aggressive person.

NewWords.WordPhrase: take care of; like or love 照料；喜欢，喜爱
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I have to say I don't much care for modern music.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. attract; give pleasure to 吸引；迷人  n.  pleasing quality; attractiveness 魅力；吸引力
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I was charmed by her slim figure and soft voice.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a person who buys goods or service 顾客，客户
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Our company is CITI Bank's most valued client.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. eat or drink; use up 吃；喝；耗尽；消费
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Michael consumes nearly a pound of cheese per day.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (AmE) biscuit 饼干
n. 公司
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Several multi-national corporations are located in the new district of Pudong.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  add (sth.) in order to make a thing more attractive to look at 装饰
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The boy decorated his room with pictures of his favorite sports figures.

NewWords.WordPhrase: prep.  in spite of 尽管；不顾
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Despite the fact that she fell midway through the race, she won.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. eat (sth.) quickly and in large quantities 狼吞虎咽地吃
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A medium-sized dog will devour at least one can of food plus biscuits per day.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a person who eats less food or only certain kinds of food 节食者；忌食某些食物的人
n. （博士）学位论文，专题论文
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is currently writing a dissertation on the Somali civil war.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 博士的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A doctoral thesis must be written in order to obtain a doctor's degree.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a rough outline or version 草稿
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My student emailed the first draft of his thesis to me yesterday.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 仙人，小精灵   fairy tale  神话故事
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was like a princess in a fairy tale.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. become weak; hesitate 变弱；犹豫
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Her voice faltered and she had to stop a moment to control it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. in a cheerful manner 鲜艳地；快乐地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He put on a gaily colored shirt.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) organize oneself and one's activities so that one does things in an effective way 将自己的各事安排得有条不紊
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Steve will have to get his act together if he is going to pass the exam. He can't just sit about doing nothing all day.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the feelings produced by belief that one has done wrong; the fact of having broken the law 内疚；有罪  guilty a. 感到内疚的，感到惭愧的；有罪的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The trial is concerned only with the determination of guilt according to criminal law.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 和谐；协调；一致
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We appreciated very much the composer's beautiful harmonies in the last movement.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 与…有关（几乎无关，很有关系）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I don't know what's the matter with Billy -- he says it's nothing to do with school.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a woman whom people admire for her courage or achievements 女英雄
(of remarks, etc.) have the intended effect (言语等) 击中要害
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I could see from her expression that his comments had hit home.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  (colloq) a fool
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. What an idiot I was to leave my suitcase on the train.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. that cannot be believed 难以置信的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It seemed incredible that people would still want to play soccer during a war.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. putting money in sth. so that it will grow 投资
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. More and more people have the desire to buy a house as an investment.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a single piece of news; a single article or unit on a list or among a set一则 一则（消息）；一条，一项，一件
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is a fascinating news item in today's China Daily.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （人坐着时）大腿的上方，膝上；（旅程的） 一段   v.（波浪）拍打
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She waited quietly with her lands in her lap.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.,n. (supposed inhabitant) of the planet Mars 火星的；（假想的）火星人
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Martian atmosphere contains only tiny amounts of water.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 军事的，军队的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The president has not ruled out the possibility of military action.

NewWords.WordPhrase: stop doing one thing and begin dealing with the next 更换（工作，话题等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She ran this shop for ten years before deciding to move on to the real estate business.

NewWords.WordPhrase: people who have power and a lot of influence 有权有势的人们
n. 小说
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The novel has been translated from English into French.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. happening sometimes but not very often 偶尔地，间或  occasional a.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I'll occasionally go to a local jazz evening with a friend.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of organizing and arranging things 有关组织方面的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The police now recognize that big organizational changes are needed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 儿科医生
n. 政治家；政客
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The mayor is a skilled politician.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. (infml) extremely, absolutely 极其，非常  positive a.  certain, sure; helpful or constructive 确信的；有益的，建设性的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This positively is the worst thing that I can even imagine.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. (fml) have or own 拥有
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is said that Michael possesses a fortune of more than two billion dollars.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 王子；亲王
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The prince won warm applause for his agitating speech.

NewWords.WordPhrase: start to write 开始动笔写
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The instant he put pencil to paper, his four-year-old son would sit beside him quietly.

NewWords.WordPhrase: do sth. quickly in order to finish it in the available time 争分夺秒地工作
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The semester is coming to an end. We have to race the clock every day to prepare for our final exams.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. not happening often 很少，难得
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Rarely have I seen a student who is so absorbed in history.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  有红格子图案的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was wearing a red-checked shirt.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the remaining time, people or things 剩下的时间（人或物）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Having finished the work, I spent the remainder of the day reading novels and listening to music.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  criticize (sb.) for failing to do sth. 责备
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She loved her boyfriend so much that she didn't reproach him for breaking his promise.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 丝带，缎带，装饰带
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She wore a red ribbon in her hair.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (in the habit of) doubting that sth. is true, right, etc. 持怀疑态度的，怀疑的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some scientists think average global temperatures have risen due to the greenhouse effect. Others are skeptical of global warming.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 世故的；老练的；复杂的；尖端的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Richard was still young, but he was sophisticated enough to know when people were not telling the truth.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  absolutely clean 十分清洁的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Even in the most spotless homes, carpets nee regular cleaning to keep them looking good.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 草莓
n.  超级市场
(pl superwomen) n. a woman having more than ordinary human powers and abilities 具有非凡才能的女性，女强人
a., n.  瑞士的；瑞士人（的）
cheat 欺骗
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was so smart that she couldn't be taken in by her colleagues.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  理论
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Einstein formulated the theory of relativity in 1905.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  音调的，声调的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is little tonal variety in his voice.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (undid, undone) vi.  disturb or upset greatly; untie, open 使烦恼，使不安，松开，解开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My daughter's idea about wealth undid me.
